subsection.title: Graphs of Inequalities in Two Variables

definition.p: A solutionsolution to an inequality in two variables is an ordered pair of numbers that satisfies the inequality.

statement.p: Find a solution to the inequality x + y \ge 10,000 for x = 2000

solution.p: For x = 2000, we have 2000 + y \ge 10,000~~~~~~\text{or}~~~~~~>y \ge 8000 You can check that any value of y greater than or equal to 8000 provides a solution when x=2000. For example, (2000, 9000) is a solution because 2000 + 9000 \gt 10,000.

sidebyside.p: We can gain some insight into the nature of the solutions if we rewrite the inequality as y \ge − x + 10,000 This inequality says that for each x-value, we must choose points with y-values greater than or equal to -x + 10,000. As we saw in the Example above, when x = 2000, the solutions have y-values greater than or equal to 8000. Solutions for x = 2000, x = 6000, and x = 11,000 are shown in the figure. Do you see a pattern emerging?

li.p: Find one y-value that satisfies the inequality y - 3x \lt 6 for each of the x-values in the table.
Graph the line y - 3x = 6. Then plot your solutions from part (a) on the same grid.

sidebyside.p: The graph of the inequality must show all the points whose coordinates are solutions. We found some solutions to the inequality x + y \ge 10,000 in the Example above by choosing a value for x and solving for y. A more efficient way to find all the solutions of the inequality is to start with the graph of the corresponding equation y = -x + 10,000

subsection.p: The graph is a straight line with slope -1. Any point above this line has a y-coordinate greater than ~-x + 10,000~ and hence satisfies the inequality. Thus, the graph of the inequality includes all the points on or above the line ~y = -x + 10,000~, as shown by the shaded region in the figure. Of course, the shaded points are also solutions to the original inequality, ~x + y \ge 10,000~.

For example, the point (-1000, ~12,000) is a solution, because -1000 + 12,000 \ge 10,000 On the other hand, the point (5000, 4000) does not lie in the shaded region because its coordinates do not satisfy the inequality.

subsection.title: Linear Inequalities
subsection.p: A linear inequalitylinear inequality can be written in the form ax + by + c \le 0 \qquad\text{ or }\qquad ax + by + c \ge 0 The solutions consist of the line ax + by + c = 0 and a half-planehalf-plane on one side of that line. We shade the half-plane to show that all its points are included in the solution set. To decide which side of the line to shade, we can solve the inequality for y in terms of x. If we obtain y \ge mx + b \qquad(\text{ or } y \gt mx + b) then we shade the half-plane above the line. If the inequality is equivalent to y \le mx + b \qquad(\text{ or } y \lt mx + b) then we shade the half-plane below the line.

sidebyside.p: We graph the corresponding line y = \frac{4}{3}x-4 with y-intercept is -4 and slope m=\dfrac{4}{3}. Finally, we shade the half-plane below the line. The completed graph is shown below.

warning.p: Be careful when isolating y. We must remember to reverse the direction of the inequality whenever we multiply or divide by a negative number. For example, the inequality -2y \alert{\gt} 6x-8 is equivalent to y \alert{\lt} {-3x}+4

subsection.p: An inequality that uses \gt or \lt instead of \ge or \le is called strictstrict. The graph of a strict inequality includes only the half-plane and not the line. In that case we use a dashed line for the graph of the equation ax + by + c = 0 to show that it is not part of the solution.

subsection.title: Using a Test Point
subsection.p: A second method for graphing inequalities does not require us to solve for y. Once we have graphed the boundary line, we can decide which half-plane to shade by using a test pointtest point. The test point can be any point that is not on the boundary line itself.

statement.p: Graph the solutions of the inequality ~~3x - 2y\lt 6

solution.p: First, we graph the line 3x - 2y = 6, as shown below. We will use the intercept method. The intercepts are (2, 0) and (0, -3), so we sketch the boundary line through those points.

Next, we choose a test point. Because (0, 0) does not lie on the line, we choose it as our test point. We substitute the coordinates of the test point into the inequality to obtain 3(\alert{0}) - 2(\alert{0}) \lt 6

sidebyside.p: Because this is a true statement, (0, 0) is a solution of the inequality. Since all the solutions lie on the same side of the boundary line, we shade the half-plane that contains the test point. In this example, the boundary line is a dashed line because the original inequality was strict.

subsection.p: Here is a summary of our test point method for graphing inequalities.

assemblage.title: To Graph an Inequality Using a Test Point:

li.p: Graph the corresponding equation to obtain the boundary line.
Choose a test point that does not lie on the boundary line.

Substitute the coordinates of the test point into the inequality.
If the resulting statement is true, shade the half-plane that includes the test point.
If the resulting statement is false, shade the half-plane that does not include the test point.
If the inequality is strict, make the boundary line a dashed line.

subsection.p: We can choose any point for the test point as long as it does not lie on the boundary line. We chose (0, 0) in because the coordinates are easy to substitute into the inequality. If the test point is a solution, we shade the half-plane including that point. If the test point is not a solution, we shade the other half-plane. For example, suppose we had chosen (5, 0) as the test point in . When we substitute its coordinates into the inequality, we find 3(\alert{5}) - 2(\blert{0}) \lt 6 which is a false statement. Thus, (5, 0) is not a solution to the inequality, so the solutions must lie on the other side of the boundary line. Note that using (5, 0) as the test point gives us the same solutions we found in .

statement.p:
Graph the solutions of the inequality y \gt \dfrac{-3}{2}x
Graph the line y = \dfrac{-3}{2}x. (Use the slope-intercept method.)
Choose a test point. (Do not choose (0, 0)!)
Decide which side of the line to shade.
Should the boundary line be dashed or solid?

warning.p: We cannot choose a test point that lies on the boundary line. In Practice 3 above, we cannot use (0, 0) as a test point, because it lies on the line y =\dfrac{-3}{2}x. In this case, we should choose some other point, such as (0, 1) or (1, 2).

subsection.p: Recall that the equation of a vertical line has the form x=k where k is a constant, and a horizontal line has an equation of the form y=k Similarly, the inequality x\ge k may represent the inequality in two variables x+0y\ge k Its graph is then a region in the plane.

solution.p: First, we graph the equation x = 2; its graph is a vertical line. Because the origin does not lie on this line, we can use it as a test point. Substitute 0 for x (there is no y) into the inequality to obtain 0\ge 2

sidebyside.p: Since this is a false statement, we shade the half-plane that does not contain the origin. We see in the figure below that the graph of the inequality contains all points whose x-coordinates are greater than or equal to 2.

subsection.title: Systems of Inequalities

sidebyside.p: Some applications are best described by a system of two or more inequalities. The solutions to a system of inequalities include all points that are solutions to each inequality in the system. The graph of the system is the intersection of the shaded regions for each inequality in the system. For example, the figure at right shows the solutions of the system y \gt x \qquad\text{ and }\qquad y \gt 2

statement.p: Laura is a finicky eater, and she dislikes most foods that are high in calcium. Her morning cereal satisfies some of her calcium requirements, but she needs an additional 500 milligrams of calcium, which she will get from a combination of broccoli, at 160 milligrams per serving, and zucchini, at 30 milligrams per serving. Draw a graph representing the possible combinations of broccoli and zucchini that fulfill Laura’s calcium requirements.

li.title: Step 1:
li.p: Number of servings of broccoli: \quad x
Number of servings of zucchini: \quad y

li.title: Step 2:
li.p: To get enough calcium, Laura must choose x and y so that 160x + 30y \ge 500 It makes no sense to consider negative values of x or of y, since Laura cannot eat a negative number of servings. Thus, we have two more inequalities to satisfy: x \ge 0 ~~~\text{ and }~~~y \ge 0

sidebyside.p: We graph all three inequalities on the same axes. The inequalities x\ge 0 and y \ge 0 restrict the solutions to lie in the first quadrant. The solutions common to all three inequalities are shown at right.

li.title: Step 4:
li.p: Laura can choose any combination of broccoli and zucchini represented by points in the shaded region. For example, the point (3, 1) is a solution to the system of inequalities, so Laura could choose to eat 3 servings of broccoli and 1 serving of zucchini.

subsection.p: To describe the solutions of a system of inequalities, it is useful to locate the verticesvertices, or corner points, of the boundary.

statement.p: Graph the solution set of the system below and find the coordinates of its vertices. x - y - 2 \amp\le 0 x + 2y - 6 \amp\le 0 x \ge 0, ~~~~~y \amp\le 0

sidebyside.p: The last two inequalities, x\ge 0 and y\ge 0, restrict the solutions to the first quadrant. We graph the line x-y-2 = 0, and use the test point (0, 0) to shade the half-plane including the origin. Finally we graph the line x - 2y - 6 = 0 and again use the test point (0, 0) to shade the half-plane below the line. The intersection of the shaded regions is shown at right.
